title: Keio Screen

source.description:
Ensure that the imaging plates have lost approximately 3-5% of their original weight. Place under a hood (or drying cabinet) until this is the case.
(Friday, -4 days)

Remove overnight cultures for 'Old Lawn' plates that were prepared in Step 24, and seed 10μl bacterial culture into each well of 4 imaging plates using the Integra ViaFlo.
(Friday, -4 days)

Fill the wells of two 96-well culture plates (Nunc™ 96-Well Polystyrene Round Bottom Microwell Plates, Non-Treated) with 200μL LB broth media and 50μg/ml Kanamycin.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Prior to the experiment, prepare 35 NGM agar-filled 60mm Petri plates (worm maintenance plates).
To make 500mL NGM agar, follow the steps in the protocol for Making normal NGM for imaging plates (Cabreiro Lab) and pour 15ml NGM agar into each plate:
(Friday, -11 days)

source.title: Making normal NGM for imaging plates (Cabreiro Lab)
source.title_html: Making normal NGM for imaging plates (Cabreiro Lab)
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"37sqq","text":"C. elegans is maintained in the laboratory on Nematode Growth Medium (NGM) agar which has been aseptically poured into petri plates. The NGM agar medium can be poured into petri plates easily and aseptically using a peristaltic pump. This pump can be adjusted so that a constant amount of NGM agar is dispensed into each petri plate. A constant amount of agar in the plates reduces the need for refocusing the microscope when you switch from one plate to another.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7a41p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"70s5t","text":"The imaging plates can be 35mm, 60mm or 90mm in diameter depending on the assay design.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"644a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Prepare 500ml NGM agar by following the steps in the protocol Making normal NGM for imaging plates (Cabreiro Lab):
(Wednesday, -6 days)

source.title: Making normal NGM for imaging plates (Cabreiro Lab)
source.title_html: Making normal NGM for imaging plates (Cabreiro Lab)
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"37sqq","text":"C. elegans is maintained in the laboratory on Nematode Growth Medium (NGM) agar which has been aseptically poured into petri plates. The NGM agar medium can be poured into petri plates easily and aseptically using a peristaltic pump. This pump can be adjusted so that a constant amount of NGM agar is dispensed into each petri plate. A constant amount of agar in the plates reduces the need for refocusing the microscope when you switch from one plate to another.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7a41p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"70s5t","text":"The imaging plates can be 35mm, 60mm or 90mm in diameter depending on the assay design.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"644a","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Remove imaging plates from 4°C storage and record the average weight of three of the plates.
(Friday, -4 days)

Remove 2 'New Lawn' and 2 'Old Lawn' seeded plates from 4°C, and dry for 30 minutes under a hood. Once dry, leave for a further 30 minutes to acclimate to room temperature.
(Monday, -1 day)

Remove the imaging plates (with L4-dispensed worms) from the 20°C incubator and leave to acclimate in the imaging cave for 30 minutes prior to tracking (+24 hours and +25 hours on food, ie. after dispensing with COPAS in Step 41).
(On Tuesday, Tracking Day 1)

Seed the remaining 25 maintenance plates with fresh BW25113 culture, and leave under hood until dry.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Inoculate 10ml LB broth media with BW25113 bacteria (used as negative control and for raising worms) for overnight culture, following the protocol, Inoculating a Liquid Bacterial Culture, and place in a shaking incubator at 37°C at 200 rpm:
(Friday, -11 days)

source.title: Inoculating a Liquid Bacterial Culture
source.description: {"blocks":[{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dp8ds","text":"Luria broth (LB) is a nutrient-rich media commonly used to culture bacteria in the lab. LB agar plates are frequently used to isolate individual (clonal) colonies of bacteria carrying a specific plasmid. However, a liquid culture is capable of supporting a higher density of bacteria and is used to grow up sufficient numbers of bacteria necessary to isolate enough plasmid DNA for experimental use. The following protocol is for inoculating an overnight culture of liquid LB with bacteria.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3q94f","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2j5df","text":"This is a general protocol for making a liquid bacterial culture and the following parameters need to be mentioned for a specific type of bacterial strain:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8b3jq","text":"1. Name of the bacterial strain","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"5eq11","text":"2. Growth temperature","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"foi7g","text":"3. Incubation time ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8km8k","text":"4. Antibiotic resistance (if any)","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6nan2","text":"5. Rpm of the shaking incubator","type":"unstyled"},{"data":[],"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6rceh","text":"","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":[]}

Seed the 10 maintenance plates with 120μL of BW25113 culture
(Saturday, -10 days)

Using a platinum pick, gently pick 7 adult N2 Bristol C. elegans onto each of the 10 seeded maintenance plates, and store in an incubator at 20°C.
(Monday, -8 days)

Remove the adult worms after 24 hours, leaving the eggs behind to hatch into L1 larvae that will be raised on BW25113.
(Tuesday, -7 days)

Inoculate 10ml LB broth media with BW25113 bacteria for overnight culture and place in a shaking incubator at 37°C, 200 rpm.
(Tuesday, -7 days)

Wash the worms off the 10 BW-seeded maintenance plates prepared in Step 4, into two 15ml Falcon tubes.
(Friday, -4 days)

The next day at about midday, wash the L1 larvae off the empty plate and re-feed onto the 25 newly seeded maintenance plates using a glass Pasteur pipette. Aim to dispense around 500 worms per plate.
(Saturday, -3 days)

Perform an egg prep on worms in the Falcon tubes, by following the protocol for Egg Prep for Bleach Synchronization (Cabreiro Lab):
(Friday, -4 days)

source.title: Egg Prep   for Bleach Synchronization (Cabreiro Lab)
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"c4q15","text":"Egg prep protocol for bleach synchronisation of C. elegans. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":12,"offset":48,"style":"italic"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Using the Integra ViaFill, dispense 200μL of NGM agar into each well of 8 imaging plates (Whatman Square Well Flat Bottom UNIPLATE), following the protocol Dispensing agar into multiwell plates:
(Wednesday, -6 days)

source.title: Dispensing agar into multiwell plates
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"fmd1o","text":"Protocol for pouring agar into 96 well plates using Integra VIAFILL dispenser. Agar should be prepared in advance, and kept in 60oC waterbath until ready to dispense, and whilst dispensing. The X, Y, Z positions for dispensing can be adjusted according to the multiwell plates being used. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"offset":129,"length":1,"style":"sup"}],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Leave the plates on the lab bench (with lids on) until the agar is dry.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Label 12 plates for harvesting L4 worms, and 13 plates for harvesting Day 1 adult worms, and incubate at 20°C.
(Saturday, -3 days)

Measure the weight of 3 plates (with lids on) and record average plate weight on day of pouring.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Store the plates upside-down at 4°C (plates can be stored for up to 1 week prior to use).
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Inoculate the 96-well culture plates from the Keio stock plate, following the protocol for Growing overnight bacterial culture in 96WP (Cabreiro Lab):
(Wednesday, -6 days)

source.title: Growing overnight bacterial culture in 96WP (Cabreiro Lab)
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"6cl0l","text":"Luria broth (LB) is a nutrient-rich media commonly used to culture bacteria in the lab. LB agar plates are frequently used to isolate individual (clonal) colonies of bacteria carrying a specific plasmid. However, a liquid culture is capable of supporting a higher density of bacteria and is used to grow up sufficient numbers of bacteria necessary to isolate enough plasmid DNA for experimental use. The following protocol is for inoculating an overnight culture of liquid LB with bacteria. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"7pbn7","text":"This is a general protocol for making a liquid bacterial culture in 96-well plate format from frozen stock plates.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"9oo94","text":"The following parameters need to be mentioned for the specific type of bacterial strains inoculated:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"coanl","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4v8sm","text":"     Parameters      Example        1. Name\/s of the bacterial strain      OP50        2. Growth temperature      37C        3. Incubation time      16-18hrs        4. Antibiotic resistance (if any)      None        5. Rpm of the shaking incubator (if needed)      200-220 rpm if required   ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":291,"offset":0}],"data":[]},{"key":"5riap","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"5k9h8","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]},{"key":"4n17u","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"tables","data":{"cellsMeta":{"0_0":"","0_1":"","1_0":"","1_1":"","2_0":"","2_1":"","3_0":"","3_1":"","4_0":"","4_1":"","5_0":"","5_1":""},"colWidths":[200,200],"data":[["  Parameters  ","  Example  "],["  1. Name\/s of the bacterial strain  ","  OP50  "],["  2. Growth temperature  ","  37C  "],["  3. Incubation time  ","  16-18hrs  "],["  4. Antibiotic resistance (if any)  ","  None  "],["  5. Rpm of the shaking incubator (if needed)  ","  200-220 rpm if required  "]],"guid":"4C53DC6A8AE811EAAF890A58A9FEAC2A","legend":"","mergeCells":[],"rowHeights":[23,23,23,23,23,23],"show_headers":true}}]}

Remove Keio frozen library stock plate from -80°C, gently remove the aluminium film, and then leave the wells to defrost for a few minutes.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Incubate thee cultures overnight at 37°C (no shaking).
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Dry the plates under a hood (or drying cabinet) until the plates lose between 3-5% of their original plate weight (with lids on)
(Wednesday, -6 days)

Repeat Steps 18 - 21 to inoculate from Keio frozen stocks again for the 'New Lawn' imaging plates (ie. freshly seeded the day before imaging).
(Friday, -4 days)

Repeat Step 21 to incubate overnight at 37°C (no shaking). These cultures ('twice removed' from frozen stocks) will be used for seeding the 'Old Lawn' imaging plates (ie. seeded 3 days prior to imaging and refrigerated).
(Thursday, -5 days)

Remove the overnight cultures from the incubator, and inoculate the newly prepared culture plates from yesterday's overnight culture plate using a replicator, following the above protocol for Growing overnight bacterial culture in 96WP (Cabreiro Lab).
(Thursday, -5 days)

Repeat Step 18 to prepare 2 more overnight culture plates.
(Thursday, -5 days)

Repeat Steps 22 - 24 for the second round of overnight cultures for the 'New Lawn' plates.
(Saturday, -3 days)

Place seeded plates under a hood to dry for 20 minutes, then place in an incubator at 25°C (no shaking) for 7 hours 40 minutes (total lawn growth time: 8 hours).
(Friday, -4 days)

After 8 hours, remove the plates from the incubator and store overnight at 4°C.
(Friday, -4 days)

Remove overnight cultures for 'New Lawn' plates that were prepared in Step 26, and seed 10μl bacterial culture into each well of 4 imaging plates using the Integra ViaFlo.
(Sunday, -2 days)

Repeat Steps 30 - 31 for the 'New Lawn' plates.
(Sunday, -2 days)

Record Day 1-dispensed worm behaviour on thee bacterial food for 15 minutes at the +24 hour timepoint.
(On Wednesday, Tracking Day 2)

Remove 12 maintenance plates with L4-stage worms (prepared in Step 11) and wash the worms off the plates into two 15ml Falcon tubes using approximately 10ml PBS 'A' buffer (sterile).
(Monday, -1 day)

Fill up the tubes to 15ml with PBA 'A' and centrifuge at 1000rpm for 2 minutes.
(Monday, -1 day)

Remove the supernatant using a Pasteur pipette.
(Monday, -1 day)

Repeat Steps 36 - 37 four more times to thoroughly rinse off any BW25113 bacteria.
(Monday, -1 day)

Re-suspend the worms and divide them equally into two 50ml Falcon tubes (for the COPAS), and fill them both up to approximately 40ml with PBS 'A'.
(Monday, -1 day)

Dispense 3 L4-stage worms into each well of the 4 imaging plates (2 'New', 2 'Old') using the COPAS following the protocol COPAS wormsorter:
(Monday, -1 day)

source.title: COPAS wormsorter
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"66sl","text":"Protocol for dispensing adult worms using the COPAS 500 flowpilot","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Turn on the COPAS machine by following Steps 1 - 16 of protocol COPAS wormsorter to prepare and clean the machine for dispensing L4-stage worms:
(Monday, -1 day)

source.title: COPAS wormsorter
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"66sl","text":"Protocol for dispensing adult worms using the COPAS 500 flowpilot","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Leave the plates to dry under a hood for 30 minutes, then incubate at 20°C overnight.
(Monday, -1 day)

Repeat Steps 34 - 40 for the 13 remaining maintenance plates with Day 1 adult worms to prepare them for COPAS.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day 1)

Dispense 3 Day 1 adult worms into each well of the 4 imaging plates (2 'New', 2 'Old') using the COPAS following the protocol COPAS wormsorter:
(Tuesday, Tracking Day 1)

source.title: COPAS wormsorter
source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"66sl","text":"Protocol for dispensing adult worms using the COPAS 500 flowpilot","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[]}

Leave the plates to dry under a hood for 30 minutes before placing them in the imaging cave to acclimate for a further 30 minutes prior to tracking using the Hydra imaging rig.
(Tuesday, Tracking Day 1)

Record L4-dispensed worm behaviour on the bacterial food for 15 minutes at the +24 hour and +25 hour timepoints (25 fps, exposure: 25000 msec, with blue-light stimulation).
(On Tuesday, Tracking Day 1)

Record Day 1-dispensed worm behaviour on thee bacterial food for 15 minutes at the +1, +3, and +5 hour timepoints.
(On Tuesday, Tracking Day 1)

Remove Day 1-dispensed imaging plates from the 20°C incubator 30 minutes prior to tracking +24 hour timepoint, and leave to acclimate in the imaging cave.
(On Wednesday, Tracking Day 2)

After imaging the +5 hour timepoint for Day 1-dispensed worms, store the Day 1-dispensed imaging plates in the 20°C incubator overnight.
(On Tuesday, Tracking Day 1)
After tracking, discard the plates in a biological waste bin.

Dry 10 maintenance plates for approximately 2 hours (depending on humidity).
(Saturday, -10 days)

Leave to dry on the bench top for about half an hour, and then store upside-down in an incubator at 25°C.
(Saturday, -10 days)

Wet some tissue with MilliQ water, and wrap the culture plates in the tissue.
NB: The tissue provides humidity that aids growth, while the presence of Kanamycin should prevent contamination.
(Wednesday, -6 days)

description: Protocol for screening Caenorhabditis elegans behavioural response to bacterial gene-deletion mutants from the 'Keio Collection', to identify behaviour-modifying mutations for follow-up analyses.
